publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: I must tell you in Prose that since I writ this, I am Loose; I think to go Orleans in a day or two from whence you shall hear from me again.

Paris 28th 08. Augt 08. NS.
1713
Good Mṛ Ford I shoud be glad to Know,
How all Affairs wtḥ you at Present go.
Whether Fresh Air at Windsor you respire,
Or breath in Town the smoak of sea coal Fire;
What Now yṛ Learned Authors are About,
And What New plays since Cato are come out.
How do the Tribe of Whiggish scriblers thrive,
Now peace is made, is Ridpath still alive?
What News from Dublin of our Friend the Dean,
And When he Talks of seeing you again?
You I suppose too woud be glad to hear,
What I & others are a doing here.
I'me·del illegible Confin'd the rest of the world is free
And Ev'ry body's happy here butt me.
T'is all my Fault & greatly I'me to blame,
Oft was I told of this before I came.
So th'·unexperienc'd youth as Ovid sings,
Still woud soar on & Melted both his Wings.
Besett wtḥ Guards I'me watch'd wtḥ greater Care,
Than ere the Fleece or golden Apples were.
O that ins with caretnow yẹ Gods a Theseus woud send,
To doze these Dogs & Carry of his Friend.
Excuse then If after wṭ I've told,
My Words are faint, my fancy not so bold.
Phoebus & yẹ Muses refuse t'inspire,
And to Anxious Mind Forbid yẹ Lyre.
No more wtḥ strength or pleasure can I write,
Than a poor soldier when he's wounded fight,
Wtḥ Ev'ry Line My Drooping spirits sink,
And still I'me more Confus'd the More I think.
Yṛ Most humble Sṭ BVanHomrighY42B563J
